subsection.heading: 1 Introduction: what counts as a passive?
subsection.p: Perhaps the first task in any work on passives is to set down what this elusive term is meant to cover. Keenan's (1985a) broad but quite detailed overview insists that passives are operations on verb phrases rather than on sentences (p. 247) for which a characteristic morphological marking is central (p. 251). Åfarli (1992: 8) summarizes this research in the following concise statement:
. . . every sentence one might reasonably want to call a passive may be minimally characterized as follows:

(22)
a. Relative to its active counterpart, the passive sentence is marked with special verb morphology.
b. The subject of the active sentence never remains subject in the passive counterpart.

This characterization of passives lays stress on the role of the subject phrase and its relation to passive morphology. The general approach to characterizing passive in terms of ‘dethematized’ subjects (those whose expected theta-role is suppressed) stems from Roberts (1987).

subsection.heading: 1.1 Two types of passives
subsection.p: Åfarli goes on to cite Keenan (1985a: 251) who “distinguishes between two broad types of passive according to the verbal morphology involved: Periphrastic passives, which necessarily make use of a passive auxiliary verb, and strict morphological passives, which do not.” Periphrastic passives are also sometimes called ‘analytic’ and strict morphological passives ‘synthetic’.

In these traditional terms, an ‘analytic passive’ is constructed with an auxiliary verb and a non-finite form of the main verb. In the bracketed passive clauses below, the usual place of the subject (underlined) contains either a noun phrase with the semantic role of what would otherwise be the main verb's object (1a) or some dummy pronoun (a null or overt ‘expletive’), as in (1b). The passive auxiliaries are italicized and the non-finite main verbs are in bold.

(1)
a. The fact that [the door was {repainted/taken off} by the tenant] upset her.
It seems that [John's requests are getting {satisfied/written down}].
b. [It might be quickly concluded that Mary is ill].
[Det vart sunge]. ‘It was sung.’ (Norwegian, from Åfarli 1992: 85)

The non-finite passive form in English, the ‘passive participle’, combines a verbal stem with a past participle suffix, thus yielding complex analytic or periphrastic passives such as be repaint-ed, be tak-en, get satisfi-ed, get writt-en; this pattern is very common throughout Indo-European languages. This suffix is (often) referred to as past, not because of the passive, but because many languages also combine this participle with different auxiliaries to form composed past tenses (the English perfect tenses have taken, the French passé composé, the Italian passato prossimo). 1 Because of the suffix's distinctive form in many irregular English verbs (broken, done, eaten, flown, gone, taken, written), it has usually been notated as -en, even when spelled -ed, since the earliest transformational work.

At least in the realm of what Baker (1988a: ch. 1) terms “grammatical function changing” rules, this analytic passive certainly reigns as ‘king’ of transformations. It is one of three singled out in Chomsky (1957) for extensive treatment and has maintained a center stage position in research ever since. This constant attention is in large part due to the fact that the correct analysis for any kind of passive remains uncertain; indeed much debate has turned on to what extent across languages and within one language the many variations on the ‘passive’ can even be considered a unitary phenomenon (Keenan 1985a; Postal 1986).

subsection.heading: 1.2 Two variants of ‘analytic passives’
subsection.p: Contributing to the uncertainty about the limits on the passive is an interesting dichotomy, widely exemplified in Indo-European systems, between what are termed verbal and adjectival passives. The construction most familiar from transformational literature is in fact a ‘verbal passive’. But a second type of passive, often homonymous with the first, is called ‘adjectival’. Wasow (1977) draws several grammatical distinctions in English, which we will review as we proceed, between verbal passives as in (2a) and adjectival passives as in (2b):

(2)
a. During my visit, that door was quickly taken off by the tenant.
John's requests are getting satisfied.
b. At my arrival, that door was already completely taken off.
John now seems very (un)satisfied.
A rough semantic characterization is that a verbal passive (2a) refers to an activity and an adjectival passive (2b) to an already attained state.

This study is devoted to sketching the history of treatments of adjectival passives in generative grammar and to selecting the elements among these treatments that seem to provide a satisfactory analysis for the construction. As the adjectival passive has much in common with periphrastic verbal passives and is often of the same form, we will necessarily be treating aspects of the latter construction. 2 However, we can exclude strict morphological (synthetic) passives from this study, relying on Åfarli's conclusions: “Among Germanic languages, the [strict morphological]-passive is unique to the Scandinavian languages” (1992: 13). “It is important to note that s-passives never have an adjectival reading” (1992: 12).

Between the periphrastic passives, the adjectival variant certainly arrived later on the generative scene (for reasons we will review), and has never become the focus of attention in the same way as the verbal passive. It has been instead confined to a relatively unexamined lexicon where its properties are supposedly relevant only to the development of ‘lexical semantics’. 3 Yet a review of literature and argumentation about the adjectival passive suggests rather that it is the more basic, minimal and diachronically constant representative of the two types. 4

In the terms of syntactic theory, this review will finally conclude not only that verbal and adjectival periphrastic passives are formed from a single lexical item, the participial suffix, but also that both involve transformational movement from object to subject for exactly the same reason. That is, I will argue that both uses of the passive suffix relate similarly to ‘NP movement’ and that neither is connected to any lexical device which relates arguments of verbs to semantic or ‘theta’-roles.

subsection.heading: 2 Verbal vs. adjectival passives: their differences
subsection.p: I first review the properties that differentiate the two types of passives, summarizing material that also appears in Emonds (2000: ch. 5). The differences in sections 2.2, 2.3, and 2.5 were brought under generative scrutiny in Wasow (1977). In this study of the generative history of adjectival passives, it is important to keep in mind that the specifically adjectival properties reviewed below were never taken as crucial considerations in formulating early versions of the passive transformation.

subsection.heading: 2.1 The interpretive difference: ongoing vs. completed activity
subsection.p: We began by examining a property that is taken in both traditional and generative grammar to distinguish passive participles with an activity sense (2a, 3a) from those indicating a resultant state (2b, 3b). The verbal passives in (2a, 3a) lack the sense of completed activity conveyed by the adjectival passives in (2b, 3b):

(3)
a. The door {got/was} closed during the noon hour. (door can be open at noon)
The door is being (*un)painted. (painting incomplete)
b. The door {remained/was} closed during the noon hour. (door closed by noon)
The door looked (un)painted. (painting complete)

Certain verbs are incompatible with this ‘completed sense’ and hence do not appear in adjectival passives. Consequently, such V can be passivized only as verbal passives; they cannot appear as complements of most verbs subcategorized as + AP: 5

(4)
*New York seems (very) {approached/left} in the tourist season.
*That good dinner felt {accompanied/followed} by too much drink.
*Many polluted cities remain {(un)avoided/escaped} during the summer.
*The clay looked (too) {handed around to students/pressed into a bowl}.
*The message appeared {slipped to the spy/put in the drawer}.
*Some basketballs sounded {dribbled across the floor/thrown against the wall}.

The sense of completed activity in (2b, 3b), i.e., of a property, seems nothing more than the characteristic Logical Form (LF) interpretation of the syntactic category A. Moreover, interpretation as a property seems to be exactly what verbal passives lack. 6 I thus propose the following at least descriptive relation between the morphology of the passive and its interpretation. Following the right hand head analysis for bound suffixes in Lieber (1980), the suffix -en is the head of the passive participle. Then, while -en is obviously present in Phonological Form (PF) in all passives:

(5)
a. In adjectival passives, the head [A -en] is present in both LF and PF.
b. In verbal passives, [A -en] is absent in LF and present only in PF. 7
Many empirical differences between adjectival and verbal passives correlate with and can be largely explained by (5). Of course, we also wish to develop a better theoretical perspective on (5).

We will see as we proceed that there is no need to invoke any further category distinction or change between the two types of passives as long as we maintain a contrast during some part of a derivation, whereby verbal but not adjectival passives lack the filled lexical head [A-en] at LF.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Selection by different classes of V
subsection.p: In most of the paradigms from Wasow (1977), the distributions of adjectival passives and underived lexical adjectives are essentially identical. This general fact follows from the presence of adjectival -en at all levels of a derivation (5a). In contrast, he considers the lack of the category A in verbal passives to be a crucial indicator of their transformational genesis. That is, while adjectival passives instantiate a category change of the stem for Wasow (morphological ‘derivation’ from V to A), verbal passives do not and could not effect a category change, because transformations lack this capability. Thus, verbal passives must be of category V. Chomsky (1981: 50) takes a somewhat different tack, proposing a special ‘neutralized category’ status for verbal passives, presumably to keep them separate from the (undiscussed) adjectival passives (see section 5.1).

Empirically, both types of Germanic and Romance passive phrases are selected by verbs whose subcategorization frames include AP, but there is a difference between adjectival and verbal passives. Adjectival passives are selected by essentially all V that select AP complements (Wasow mentions English act, appear, be, become, look, remain, seem, smell, and sound), while only one or two such ‘auxiliary’ V in each language select verbal passives. Under either Wasow's or Chomsky's categorial proposals, (5a) certainly explains at least the first part of this statement. Nonetheless, neither proposal clarifies why Indo-European verbal passives are compatible with only one or two ‘passive auxiliaries’ otherwise specified as + AP (e.g., be and get).

subsection.heading: 2.3 Degree words freely modify only (certain) adjectival passives
subsection.p: There are not fully understood differences among adjectival passives as to which permit a full range of characteristic adjectival modifiers, so-called ‘degree words’, as in (6a). 8 In any case, verbal passives do not tolerate them. By using either a progressive or the verbs in (4) (approached/avoided/handed, etc.) to ensure that a passive is verbal rather than adjectival, we create ungrammatical combinations with adjectival modifiers (6b).

(6)
a. The garden seemed too overplanted.
New York remains more affected by strikes than other cities.
That region doesn't seem very inhabited.
How spotted with food did those clothes look?
b. The garden is being (*too) overplanted.
*New York is more avoided by tourists than other cities.
*That prison doesn't seem very escaped these days.
*How handed around to students did the clay feel?

Though a full theory of grammatical modification remains to be worked out, the following seems to be a minimal requirement: Many, perhaps all, items that modify only lexical category X0 (here A) require that this X0 be lexicalized throughout a derivation. The structural contrast (5) then lays the basis for correlating free adjectival modification with the presence of a lexical entry under A. Since the -en suffix on a verbal passive is absent in LF (5b), these forms don't tolerate degree words.

The distinction between lexicalized passive adjectives and those resulting from productive syntactic derivation is studied in more detail in Emonds (2000: ch. 5), in relation to determining possible modifiers of adjectival passives. In that approach, fully lexicalized members of this class (affected, inhabited, restricted, worried) are suffixed in the lexicon and hence throughout a derivation, and so can be modified by degree words. Other adjectival passives (destroyed, lost, painted, planted) are formed in the syntax, i.e., they are not adjectives throughout a derivation, and hence do not tolerate degree words. 9

subsection.heading: 2.4 Passives with the adjectival prefix un-
subsection.p: This test distinguishing verbal from adjectival passives dates from Siegel (1973). Passives prefixed with un- can appear as complements of verbs that take APs as in (7a), while verbal passives cannot. So prefixing un- to the verb stems in (4), which are compatible with only verbal passives, creates the impossible italicized combinations (7b), no matter what the wider context:

(7)
a. That work seemed {unknown/unpainted/unrewarded}.
Those books should remain {untouched/unfinished/unsold}.
b. *That work {was/seemed} {unleft in good hands/unfollowed by others}.
*Those books should {get/remain} {unthrown/unhanded} to any customers.
As in the previous subsection, it appears that if a prefix modifies only members of lexical category X0, then X0 should be lexicalized throughout a derivation.

Bresnan (1978: 6–9) claims that this pattern precludes using transformational movement in adjectival passives in, e.g., (7a). However, the assumptions of her argument seem to be that passive movement is restricted to V-headed clauses (begging the question) and that all operations contributing to a transformed passive surface structure occur simultaneously (which is currently not assumed).

subsection.heading: 2.5 Only verbal passives have the full internal structure of surface VPs
subsection.p: As observed by Wasow (1977: 341), verbal passives essentially recreate the full range of structures found in active VPs, except that the passive VP contains one gap e for the DP which is ‘passivized’: Mary was (being) elected e President; Sue was sent e the letter. They are thus unlike adjectival passives, which fail to appear in such contexts: Mary felt {happy/*elected President}; *Sue was unsent the letter.

Åfarli (1992: chs. 3–4) shows that Norwegian passives with expletive subjects in fact exhibit a full range of active VP structures. Similarly, the ‘gapless’ Japanese passive VPs analyzed in Kubo (1992) contain one or two object DPs exactly like their active counterparts; and Japanese ‘gapped’ passive VPs also contain direct objects and other complements, except for the single ‘passivized’ DP.

In contrast, adjectival passives exhibit a significantly smaller range of syntactic patterns. In particular, they tolerate no overt bare complement DPs not in surface PPs: *Bill sounded offered a dinner. Nor can their subjects correspond to derived rather than deep direct objects: *John sounds considered to be a scoundrel; *There seems believed to be corruption in high places (Wasow 1977: 344). We return in section 5.2 to an account of these limitations. I will suggest that the best currently available analysis depends in part on the morphological distinction in (5a, b) and in part on other independently justified aspects of grammatical theory.

subsection.heading: 2.6 Only verbal passives have external arguments
subsection.p: Many studies (to name some: Chomsky 1965: ch. 2; Wasow 1977, section 4.3; Jaeggli 1986a, section 6; Åfarli 1989, section 1.2.2.1; Schoorlemmer 1995, section III.1.1) have contributed to establishing a widely accepted claim that a verbal passive is always related to a syntactically present noun phrase that acts as its logical subject, either a by phrase or a covert DP. Verbal passives (8) thus contrast with adjectival passives (9), which lack such arguments.

(8)
a. The meeting was started on time (by Susan) (in order) to please the host.
b. The chairs were moved around on purpose (by the guests).
c. This corn has been grown voluntarily ({by peasants/to stave off famine}).
d. Our workers are better paid intentionally (by the new boss).
e. Art classes are being restored (by the Board) in order to qualify for funding.

(9)
a. That series of meetings sounds completed (*by the committee).
b. Most of our furniture is still unmoved (*by the company).
c. We judge the corn fully grown ({*voluntarily/*to stave off famine}).
d. Our workers remain better paid (*intentionally).
e. Some art classes seem restored (*in order to qualify for funding).
The works just cited propose that an overt by phrase or corresponding covertly represented logical subject accounts for two widely recognized properties of verbal passives:
(10) This logical subject may (not necessarily must) control the optional PRO subject of a ‘higher’ infinitive of purpose, optionally introduced by in order, as in (8a, c, e).
(11) A syntactically present animate subject seems to be a necessary condition for adverbs of intentionality, as in (8b, c, d), and for that matter, for adjunct purpose clauses as well.

Given this ‘special location’ of the external argument in passives, we want to know why verbal passives must, but adjectival passives must not, have such a structurally represented overt or covert DP subject. (We are not yet accounting for the ‘dethematicization’ property, i.e., why these external arguments are located in a by phrase rather than in the surface position that potentially agrees with the verb; this will be discussed in section 8.2.)
We know that verbs generally require subjects in LF – this follows from the Extended Projection Principle (‘EPP’) of Chomsky (1981). (12) seems like a workable formulation of this idea:
(12) Extended Projection Principle at LF (EPP). A verb must have a structural subject phrase if and only if the verb is a lexical head of a constituent in LF.

This formulation exempts ‘empty auxiliaries’ such as passive and perfect auxiliaries from the EPP; on their own such verbs plausibly lack inherent content, and concomitantly they seem to impose no requirement of having their own subject. Perhaps more to the point here, verbs in compounds and derivational morphology such as those in bold in meet ing place, dish wash ing, think tank, go cart, infest ation, bereave ment, etc. also lack syntactically specified subject phrases, overt or covert.
To see how (12) applies to passive structures, let us look again at the preliminary characterization (5) of the difference between adjectival and verbal passives.

(5)
a. In adjectival passives, the head [A -en] is present in both LF and PF.
b. In verbal passives, [A -en] is absent in LF and present only in PF.

(5a) straightforwardly exempts adjectival passives from (12), because the V stem of an adjectival passive is not the lexical head of the construction at LF. The V stems in adjectival passives resemble rather the subjectless initial V in compounds and derivational morphology. In fact, this construction is traditionally treated as an example of the latter. That is, a V inside a passive adjective is simply not subject to the EPP, which accounts for the pattern (9).

On the other hand, according to (5b), the stem V is the only candidate for being the lexical head of a verbal passive phrase in LF, precisely because [A -en] is absent. This V then is subject to the EPP (12), which forces the presence of a subject. As mentioned above, we return in section 8.2 to why this subject is not realized in the usual ‘nominative’ position but must rather be covert or in a by phrase. 10

subsection.heading: 2.7 Idiomatic object nouns passivize freely only in verbal passives
subsection.p: There remains a final contrast between adjectival and verbal passives concerning idiomatic V-NP combinations. That is, adjectival passives disallow any semantic relation other than ‘pure argumenthood’ between a subject DP and the participle's V stem, as seen in the contrasts in (13).

(13)
Some advantage may finally {be/*feel} taken of our new wealth.
A great deal {was/*sounded} made of your visit.
No attention {is being paid/*seems paid} to minor officials.

Actually, this kind of contrast can be related to a difference between so-called ‘inflectional’ and ‘derivational’ morphology, although the confusion over the nature of this distinction limits the usefulness of this reduction. Thus, a verb formed with another fully productive inflection, the -ing of the gerund or present participle, allows idiomatic combinations like maintain silence, pay attention, please DP no end and bore DP to tears in (14).

(14)
During the trial, all were impressed by John's maintaining silence.
His paying {bribes/attention} to minor officials was foolish.
This show is pleasing local kids no end.
They heard Mary boring us to tears.
But in derivational formations such as the nominals and adjectives in (15), idioms don't survive.

(15)
*During the trial, all were impressed by John's maintenance of silence.
His payment of {bribes/*attention} to minor officials was foolish.
This show seems pleasing to local kids (*no end).
Mary sounded so boring (*to tears).
Consequently, the contrasts in passive paradigms with idioms as in (13) suggest that verbal passives are inflectional like gerunds, while adjectival passives are not.

The explanation seems to be that idiomatic combinations of heads and arguments tolerate no intervening heads in LF. 11 Once again in accord with the structure (5a), the intervening lexical item [A -en] at LF blocks idiomatic combinations of Vs and phrasal complements in adjectival passives, whereas the absence of [A -en] in the verbal passive LFs (5b) has no effect and hence allows them. 12

We have now reviewed seven differences between adjectival and verbal passives, which have been discussed in various works on passives in English and other languages. We have been able to attribute six of these differences, at least in part, to the distinction between a structure for adjectival passives (5a), in which a lexicalized A is present in LF, and one for verbal passives (5b), whose adjectival head is not lexicalized at LF, but only at PF.

Nonetheless, the genesis of the distinctive properties of the two kinds of passives in the terms just developed remains somewhat mysterious. We have not elucidated what is perhaps syntactically the most important of these differences, that of section 2.5: only verbal passives have the full internal structure of surface VPs. Moreover, we would like to understand better the structural difference (5) that underlies several of the others. Finally, there remains the question of formally accounting for Åfarli's ‘essential property of the passive’: how does the special morphology of a passive guarantee that the subject of an active sentence never remains an (agreeing) subject in either kind of passive? In my view a satisfactory answer can be given (only) by treating verbal and adjectival passives together.

The next four sections follow the history of the treatments of adjectival passives, and will provide an account of why verbal passives have the internal structure of surface VPs rather than of APs. Then, the last two sections of the study will situate (5) in a theory of lexical insertion and propose an account of the passive's essential ‘dethematicization’ of an active verb's subject.

subsection.heading: 3 Adjectival properties of all passives
subsection.p: For two decades prior to Wasow (1977), transformational grammar was largely content to treat verbal passives as the only passives worthy of the name. In particular, Chomsky's early analyses of the passive (1957: ch. 5; 1965: ch. 2) laid particular stress on properties just reviewed in sections 2.1 and 2.5: verbal passive clauses are transformationally derived because they are largely synonymous with corresponding actives, and the characteristic constituent sequences one finds in verbal passive clauses are systematically related to base configurations. Passive sequences are exactly those we expect if VPs have precisely one NP transformationally ‘removed’ from them.

However, certain theoretical developments in the early 1970s led to questioning this claim that the passive involves movement. Although the revisionist view seems in retrospect to have been a ‘mistake’ – moreover one quickly rectified via Wasow (1977) – correcting this mistake led to a second misconception concerning adjectival passives that persists today. 13

An alternative analysis of the English verbal passive in Hasegawa (1968) had faulted Chomsky's earlier formulations as implausible amalgams of “too many elementary transformations,” including movement leftward, movement rightward, auxiliary insertion, and optional deletion of an agent phrase. Under the influence of this critique, Chomsky (1970) reanalyzed the passive as two independent subrules, preposing of a deep object into a subject position (NP-preposing), and demotion of a deep subject into a postposed PP headed by the P by (agent-postposing). At the same time, these two operations were used in Emonds (1970, 1976) to illustrate the notion of ‘structure-preservation’, namely, categories generated in the base component were moved into positions where the phrase structure rules of the base could actually also generate these same categories. 14

Now the motivations for postulating transformationally derived status, widely circulated at this time and later published in Lakoff and Ross (1976), were (i) possible simplifications in the base component, (ii) allowing simpler definitions of grammatical relations in terms of base structures, and (iii) permitting simplified statements of co-occurrence restrictions on lexical insertion. If transformational outputs of NP-preposing and agent postposing could be generated by independently needed base rules, there remained only two possible (nonetheless non-trivial) motivations for them, (ii) and (iii).

This led some analysts to hypothesize that the passive constructions derived by structure-preserving operations, and thus lacking the motivation (i) for transformations, might simply be base-generated constructions full stop. Freidin (1975: section 2) argued that certain aspects of Chomsky's two NP movement rules, especially the agent postposing rule, were problematic. He further claimed that certain passive properties were similar to, and should be subsumed under, those of base-generated adjective phrases. I now treat each of these four adjectival properties of verbal passives in separate subsections.

subsection.heading: 3.1 An AP pattern inside passive phrases?
subsection.p: The phrase structure of adjective phrases is generally taken to preclude the possibility of multiple NP sisters to the adjectival head. Freidin's (1975: 401) rule (47) expresses this:
If a passive participle is analyzed as an A, many varied examples of passive constructions indeed conform to his rule. The brackets represent AP boundaries:

(17)
The letter was [given to Ann].
The station was (being) [approached from two sides].
How much unfair advantage was [taken of Bill]?

(18)
Ann was [given the letter].
Who got [taken such unfair advantage of]?
A lot of vacation was (being) [allowed the workers].
The workers were (being) [allowed a lot of vacation].
That letter was [sent all the candidates].
Peter was (being) [forgiven his sins].
Peter's sins were (being) [forgiven him].
He was (being) [charged a lot of money].

Wasow (1977: 341) however sharply criticizes (16), claiming: “There is no other construction in English that requires rule (47),” and supports his criticism with extensive argument (his long note 10). Note that most of the overt surface NPs in Freidin's putative APs in (18) are typically and crucially ‘bare’, i.e., they lack an overt P. Such a complement type is quite unusual with head As in English and many languages, and thus the lack of a structural PP for these complements seems unexplained. 15
A descriptive generalization (19) that better covers the range of complements observed in (17–18) is unrelated to the range of structures lexically chosen by head As:
(19) English passive verbs take exactly the same range of complement combinations as active verbs, except that one noun phrase is missing in a passive structure.

Thus, the variation in passive verb complement types in (17–18) matches that of identical active verbs in (20), except for the presence in each example of (20) of an additional italicized noun phrase.

(20) give the letter to Ann, approach the station from two sides, take such unfair advantage of Bill, give Ann the letter, allow the workers a lot of vacation, send all the candidates that letter, forgive Peter his sins, charge him a lot of money.

It is of course the correlation in (19) that originally led Chomsky to propose a transformational treatment of the passive, although it is unclear how many construction types he had in mind. This same correlation led most syntacticians in Chomsky's surround back to a movement analysis of verbal passives, despite the challenges in Freidin (1975) and Bresnan (1978, 1982d).

In the meantime, however, this challenge and Wasow's (1977) response succeeded in making the field aware of the adjectival properties of analytic passives, three more of which will now be discussed. As will be seen later in this study, only after quite a long period of ambivalence about the categorial status of participles have analyses of the passive emerged which use a synthesis of both transformational movement and a central role for the category A.

subsection.heading: 3.2 The choice of the passive auxiliary
subsection.p: Freidin (1975: 402) observes that the English ‘passive auxiliary’ be – the same can be said for its second passive auxiliary get – is in any case subcategorized for taking AP complements (cf. section 2.2 above). This lexical property follows from analyzing passives as base-generated adjectives. In contrast, if the passive auxiliary is generated separately in a base rule for an AUX constituent, it is subject to several ad hoc restrictions. Moreover, if it is transformationally inserted, its resemblance to other base-generated auxiliary structures seems strangely fortuitous.

More generally, both types of passives are selected by verbs that have the lexical frame + AP. In fact, Wasow (1977) notes that adjectival passives appear as complements of almost all Vs whose subcategorization frames include + AP or + DP^(AP). For example, English intransitives such as act, appear, be, become, feel, look, remain, seem, smell, sound, stay, and taste all accept APs, including adjectival passives:
(21) She {felt/seemed/sounded/found him/considered Bill} {ill/betrayed/cared for}.

Although verbal passives are selected by only two linking verbs, Freidin correctly observes that these also have the frame + AP. 16 Thus, analyzing all analytic passives as adjectives at least explains why both variants inevitably appear as complements of Vs that are + AP or + DP^(AP). But still, one wonders why so few verbs select verbal passive complements.

An account of this puzzle is presented in Emonds (2000: ch. 5). Passive auxiliaries, i.e., those V that select verbal passives, are invariably among the ‘grammatical V’ of a given language, that is, those V which lack purely semantic features and hence, in that framework, can be inserted late in a derivation. Now clearly, it is the passive participle morpheme [A -en] itself that creates an insertion context AP for passive auxiliaries, and the insertion of this purely grammatical element is itself part of PF. Consequently, a V can select a verbal passive only if it is (i) uninterpreted at LF (i.e., inserted in PF), and also (ii) has the frame + AP. Be and get are the only such V. I know of no other principled account of why so few verbs can select verbal passive complements. 17

subsection.heading: 3.3 The adjectival character of participial morphology
subsection.p: By taking the passive participle as simply an adjective, Freiden (1975) also explains certain aspects of the morphology of a range of Germanic, Romance, and Slavic analytic passives. First, as Lieber (1980) and Bresnan (1982d: 21–24) discuss in some detail, the irregular forms in verbal passives almost exactly mimic items of the same form that are clearly adjectival. 18
(22) being written, seems written; being done, seems done; being stung, seems stung; etc.
Exceptional: being {burned/*burnt}; looks {?burned/burnt}

The full similarity leads them to endorse a rule of ‘conversion’, which adds the category A by brute force to verbal participles for the formation of passive adjectives, a procedure also endorsed in Levin and Rappaport (1986). That is, these authors argue that separate lexical formation rules would miss a generalization that the same morphological structure is involved.

Second, in whichever contexts an adjective agrees with a modified nominal in Romance and Germanic languages, both adjectival and verbal uses of the passive participle agree as well. For example, Romance adjectives typically agree in number and gender with modified nominals in both attributive and predicative positions. Therefore, both adjectival (23a) and verbal passives (23b) in French exhibit feminine (plural) agreements via the bold -e(s) in exactly the same positions. 19

(23)
a. A mon arrivée, ces jolies
portes semblaient déjà {repeintes /grises }.
at my arrival, those pretty doors seemed already {repainted/gray}
‘At my arrival, those pretty doors seemed already {repainted/gray}.’
b. Cette jolie
porte était vite repeinte
par le locataire pendant ma visite.
that pretty door was quickly repainted by the renter during my visit.
‘That pretty door was quickly repainted by the renter during my visit.’

When only attributive adjectives agree, as in German, then both uses of the passive participle agree in and only in the same attributive contexts. Further, both German adjectives and passive participles agree in number, gender, and case. Within some Slavic systems, similar inflectional parallels between verbal and adjectival passive participles are also common. For Russian, they are outlined in Schoorlemmer (1995: section IV.1.1).

Uniformly analyzing all passive participles as adjectives thus explains the fact that adjectival and passive agreements share both their morphology and their syntax in several language systems. Note further that adjectival agreement is unlike verb agreement in the languages in question (verbs agree with subjects in person but not in gender), and so the argument goes beyond an appeal to undifferentiated ‘agreement’.

In view of Lieber's (1980) right hand head analysis of bound morphology, the morpho-syntactic properties of participles reviewed in this section suggests a partial lexical entry (24) for all passive participles, both verbal and adjectival.
(24) Passive participles (partial lexical entry): en, A, + V , . . .
The realizations of this entry at the PF and LF interfaces are those given above in (5):

(5)
a. In adjectival passives, the head [A -en] is present in both LF and PF.
b. In verbal passives, [A -en] is absent in LF and present only in PF.
One means of expressing (24) and (5b) together is to postulate that a structure [A V − [A Ø]] can be generated syntactically and be lexically filled in either syntax (5a) or only at PF (5b). 20

subsection.heading: 3.4 The AP distribution of passive participles
subsection.p: Phrases with heads of passive form and lexical adjective phrases appear to modify nouns and verbs as ‘adjuncts’ under basically the same conditions. Passive participles can be adjuncts of sentences (25a), of verb phrases (25b) and attributive modifiers of nouns (25c), all of which are characteristic positions of predicate adjectives:

(25)
a. {Desolate/Unwanted/Rejected}, the child turned to crime.
b. The child spent its school years {hungry/uncared for/bullied}.
c. Church bells {silent/rung} at noon reflect the status of the clergy.
It's patients {unable to pay/left to wait/examined hastily} that leads to problems.

An additional distributional argument for the adjectival status of passive participles can be constructed around the usage of the particle as as a ‘prepositional copula’. Like the copula be, non-comparative as takes a predicate attribute NP or AP; cf. Emonds (1985: ch. 6). The fact that passive participles can be complements to this prepositional copula then becomes another argument for their adjectival status.
(26) He {struck us/treated them} as {intelligent/ill/experienced/undernourished}.

We can thus conclude with Freidin that all passive clauses share in the morphology and the syntax of adjective phrases AP, especially as regards their interaction with material external to AP: agreement with a subject, selection by external heads, and distribution as adjuncts. The differences between verbal and adjectival passives reviewed in section 2 turn rather around the syntax internal to passive phrases: how they are interpreted, whether they can contain idioms, how their heads can be modified, how they internally arrange phrases, and whether they contain interpreted subjects.

subsection.heading: 4 Lexical redundancy rules vs. Anderson's ‘Theme Rule’
subsection.p: Given the several adjectival properties of all analytic passives, it is not surprising that Freidin proposed to assimilate both types passives to the category of base-generated adjective phrases. In fact, the arguments above in sections 3.2 through 3.4 retain some force. But then, as observed in Freidin (1975: 291), if “. . . the synonymy of active–passive pairs is not explicitly accounted for by a rule in the syntactic or semantic component, a grammar that captures the active–passive relation must include a rule that does so.” As a consequence, he looked elsewhere to explain the second motivation for a transformational movement: why do main lexical verbs assign a semantic function (theta-role) to the surface subject of passives in the same way as they assign a role to an object NP in active sentences? Once this explanation was found, it supposedly would simultaneously explain any selectional and subcategorization co-occurrence restrictions on lexical insertion of passive forms, thus removing the third possible motivation (cf. p. 26) for movement in passives.

The device first favoured by this line of research was the ‘lexical redundancy’ condition or rule, based on extending certain ideas for complex lexical entries in Chomsky (1970). Freidin (1975: section 3) develops such a system, including a general condition for assigning synonymy to projections from similar lexical entries, a general specification of the form of multi-category entries, and a specific redundancy condition that stipulates positional relations between the semantic functions of an active verb and those of a passive verb. 21 Similarly, for adjectival passives only, Wasow (1977: section 4.2) endorses a type of lexical redundancy rule developed in Jackendoff (1976).

The field did not take long to react against a second type of formal device for assigning the same predicate–argument relations to differently situated arguments, however. On the one hand, Anderson's (1977) commentary on Wasow's essay (peer responses follow the papers in this ground-breaking volume) endorses a lexical treatment at least of adjectival passives, in line with grammatical thinking of the time: “The criteria Wasow proposes for distinguishing rules of the two types [lexical and transformational] are entirely natural and well-motivated ones within the general conception of grammar developed as the Extended Standard Theory . . . There is an obvious advantage to making the subclass of lexical redundancy rules as large as possible” (p. 364). On the other hand, however, his main aim is to “arrive at a narrower and more interesting conception of the lexical redundancy rules, [so] that some of the problems arising in Wasow's paper receive a satisfying account” (p. 366).

Anderson then proceeds to implement the following critique of lexical redundancy rules. “The association between grammatical and thematic relations, then, ought not to be stated in each lexical entry, but ought rather to be stated once and for all as a general rule: part of the semantic component of a grammar of English, or (conceivably) part of a semantic meta theory” (p. 367). His main proposal then follows: the semantic roles of NPs in adjectival passive clauses are determined by what he terms the Theme Rule (and states only informally): “the Theme is quite generally to be found in Subject position if the verb is intransitive, and in Direct Object position if the verb is transitive” (p. 367). The task of the lexicon then reduces to separately listing intransitive forms such as, e.g., break, broken, close and closed, and (let me add) taken, eaten, painted, (over)planted, (un)inhabited, but not verbs such as take, eat, paint, (over)plant, or inhabit:

(27)
a. The door may {break/seem broken/close/seem closed}.
b. This apartment may seem {taken/painted} during your visit.
The park will soon look {(over)planted/(un)inhabited}.
c. *This apartment may {take/paint} during your visit.
*The park will soon {(over)plant/inhabit}.

But Anderson's lexical entries would not have to say anything, via item-particular stipulations and/or lexical redundancy rules, about how subjects and objects receive thematic roles; that would be the province of the Theme Rule. and in fact, Williams (1981a) soon postulates a more formal version of the Theme Rule, positing a direct relation between bound morphemes such as -en and the syntactic position of thematic roles, i.e., with -en, the Theme must be the external argument.

Lest terminology confuse the issue, we should emphasize that for Anderson the italicized phrases in (28) are Themes, unlike many lexical semantic treatments that would assign them Locational type theta-roles.

(28)
A vandal smeared my house with the paint. (p. 369)
The result annoyed John. (p. 372)
The garden swarmed with bees. (p. 369)
George Washington slept in this bed. (p. 373, with the passivizable sense of ‘affecting’ the bed)
Anderson's proposal and Williams's Theme Externalization are thus close to expressing a generalization (29) that will be important below:
(29) The subject of (always intransitive) adjectival passives relates semantically to the verb root like the direct object of corresponding transitive verbs.

We should keep in mind that various formulations of the Theme Rule don't explain, without having recourse to redundant stipulations, why passive adjectives are more easily formed than intransitive verbs. We return to this in section 6. Nonetheless, Anderson's proposal, to the extent it was appreciated, obviated the need for syntactic theory to countenance a type of lexical redundancy device which ‘doubles’ the grammatical function changing work of transformations.

Another response to the momentary focus on adjectival passives was more direct. In his seminal article on trace theory, Fiengo (1977) proposed deriving them by using Chomsky's object-preposing inside AP. While his brief formal treatment for interpreting these passives seems inadequate, he nonetheless finds a weak spot in the lexicalist opposition: contemporary argument against deriving adjectival passives via movement seemed to beg the question; it assumed without argument that NP movement doesn't apply in an AP domain.

In any case, works like Anderson (1977) led to transformationalists losing interest in lexical redundancy rules, though of course a framework that lost interest in transformations, namely Lexical Functional Grammar, continued to develop the notion of ‘lexical relatedness’ in terms of lexical ‘functional structures’ (Bresnan 1978) and ‘predicate argument structures’ (Bresnan 1982d).

subsection.heading: 5 The relation of passive participles to case assignment
subsection.p: Before continuing to review analyses specific to adjectival passives, let us investigate the relation of passives to abstract case, a factor which could have – but did not – figure in distinguishing the two types of passive. Traditional grammars of European inspiration have frequently related passive structures to the failure of accusative case assignment. In turn, this failure seems somehow related to the adjectival nature of all passive participles and the fact that adjectives do not in general assign accusative case. A role for case along these lines became a central aspect in government and binding analyses of the verbal passive in the eighties, and in my view, could have led to quicker progress had it been formulated with the properties of adjectival passives in mind.

subsection.heading: 5.1 Chomsky's Case-driven analysis
subsection.p: In his initial authoritative treatise on government and binding, Chomsky (1981: 48–50) observes that the fundamental property of (verbal) passives may be either one of two options:
(30) Something forces a passivized object NP to move away from its base position.
(31) Something deprives a passive subject position of its usual theta-role and thereby renders it a landing site for movement.

In terms of the then recent incorporation of abstract case into generative syntax, a plausible motivation for forcing movement could be lack of case on a passive verb's object NP, in turn due to the verb's adjectival morphology. Chomsky (1981) thus opts to develop (30) on the basis of a ‘Case Filter’, by virtue of which overt noun phrases lacking case at the end of a derivation render a structure ill-formed. 22 The contemporary debates about the relation of passive participles to the category A most likely played a role in attributing forced movement in passives to the adjectival form of the V.

However, if one straightforwardly claimed that verbal passive participles are As, then essentially nothing would structurally differentiate verbal from the adjectival passives, which had been consigned to the distant lexicon; Wasow's defense of a transformational passive seemingly depended on maintaining a difference between verbal passive participles and the category A. Thus, verbal passive participles should ‘act like’ As and yet be not quite entirely As. The solution suggested by Chomsky (1981: 50) is to assign them to a special, “unspecified for ±N” neutralized category. In Case Theory, whose Case Assigning categories are V and P (in terms of features −N), the +N categories N and A fail to assign case (Stowell 1981). Chomsky's implied revision of Case Theory is that the categorial features of verbal passive participles, namely [+V, unspecified for N], do not assign case either, which then accounts for (30).

This proposal turns into an equivocation, however, because on the next page Chomsky (1981: 51) suggests that of in the context N___NP has the features [−V, unspecified for N] and does assign case. Hence, an ad hoc ‘neutralized category’ (unspecified for N) of highly defective distribution (with only two members, -en and of) leads not to a definition of a natural class of case assigners somehow related to [−N]), but rather to item-particular stipulations.

In spite of this shaky foundation, the voluminous literature of government and binding in the eighties maintains (and proclaims) this analysis with almost one voice: the mantra was ‘lack of case forces movement in the passive’. This literature also uniformly presupposes Wasow's conclusion that only verbal passives involve movement; cf. again note 3. More than a decade later, Åfarli (1992: section 1.2.3.1) reviews the unchanged ‘Orthodox Analysis’, including the factor that the participle is a “neutralized [+V] category . . . and like adjectives, it is a bad Case assigner.”

subsection.heading: 5.2 Rethinking the full internal VP structures
subsection.p: Government and binding analyses of the passive were slow to challenge Chomsky's choice of (30) over (31). Roberts (1987: ch. 2) reformulated the relation to case assignment in terms of a passive verb assigning ‘all but one’ of its cases, and began to focus more on properties of a passive's ‘dethematized’ subject. Cross-linguistic studies of passives, including Åfarli's, finally undermined the choice of (30) over (31). 23 They reason on the basis that verbal passive constructions in several languages can exhibit overt direct objects, even with morphological accusative case.

Some examples include Sobin (1985) on the impersonal passives of Ukrainian, Åfarli (1989, 1992) on the wider range of such constructions in Norwegian, and Kubo (1992) on the ‘adversative’ and dative passives of Japanese. Åfarli (1989: 23) rejects (30), arguing “on the basis of Norwegian data that passive verbs assign Case just like their active counterparts do . . . [and] that this is also essentially correct for English . . .” He concludes (1989: 102) rather in favor of (31): “the essential property of the passive phenomenon is that the subject position of a passive clause is theta-free and thus becomes a possible landing site for NP movement.” 24 In what follows, I will refer to this as ‘the essential property of the passive’.

More prosaically, even very familiar facts of English cast doubt on whether a verbal passive in any way interferes with case assignment. The examples of (18), repeated here, contain a range of italicized objects to which prima facie, a passive V assigns case. 25

(18)
Ann was [given the letter].
Who got [taken such unfair advantage of]?
A lot of vacation was (being) [allowed the workers].
The workers were (being) [allowed a lot of vacation].
That letter was [sent all the candidates].
Peter was (being) [forgiven his sins].
Peter's sins were (being) [forgiven him].
He was (being) [charged a lot of money].
Put differently, since verbal passives have the full internal structure of VPs (the property noted in section 2.5), all these VPs with a single gap are well-formed. 26

In interesting contrast to these verbal passives, the corresponding adjectival passives based on the ‘double object constructions’ in (32), as observed in Wasow (1977), are always ill-formed. Levin and Rappaport (1986: section 4) also note these effects for adjectival passives, but do not pursue the implications of the contrast with verbal passives.

(32)
*Ann seemed given the letter.
*That letter sounded sent all the candidates.
*Who acted taken such unfair advantage of?
*Peter felt (un)forgiven his sins.
*Peter's sins stayed forgiven him.
*Those workers appeared allowed a lot of vacation.
*He felt (un)charged too much money.

Had syntacticians retained an interest in adjectival passives, they could have concluded that the Case Filter accounts naturally for this regular ungrammatical pattern, because an A can assign case neither to an NP that moves nor to one that stays in its base position. The fact the Case Filter successfully excludes these examples suggests that a proper movement analysis, counter to the government and binding consensus, might be capable of explaining the other systematic syntactic restrictions on adjectival passives: that they are incompatible with derived, non-deep direct objects (section 2.5) and idiomatic objects (section 2.7).

Summarizing, like other adjectives, the participles in (32) with right hand word-internal A heads simply fail to assign case to any VP-internal DPs not targeted by NP movement. Consequently, adjectival passive phrases can't contain such DPs. In contrast, nothing stops a verbal passive from assigning case to these ‘second DPs’. This contrast in case-assigning capability is actually another property that follows from the earlier partial structural characterizations of the two passive types:

(5)
a. In adjectival passives, the head [A -en] is present in both LF and PF.
b. In verbal passives, [A -en] is absent in LF and present only in PF.
That is, in (5a) the A head prevents case assignment, but in (5b) the V head assigns case normally. What causes movement in passives is thus not lack of case.

As in note 7, there are different ways to realize this LF distinction in passives (5): (i) Derivation – a participial suffix could be entirely absent in verbal passives in the syntax, with [A -en] added to a V in PF. (ii) LF Feature Checking – the suffix [A -en] is present in both passives in the syntax, but is checked off (i.e., deleted) in LF only in verbal passives. (iii) Late Insertion – the suffixal A node is present in both passives; it is already lexicalized in syntax as -en in adjectival passives, but in verbal passives it is empty in the syntax and lexicalized only in PF.

For understanding the history of passive analyses, the choice among (i–iii) need not concern us. The Derivation alternative (i) reflects an early generative impulse, but seems unlikely because it does not explain why verbal passives are selected by auxiliaries with a feature + AP and generally appear in syntactic AP positions (sections 3.2 and 3.4). 27 Alternatives (ii) and (iii) are currently more plausible accounts of (5). The next section briefly examines empirical grounds for favoring Late Insertion (iii), but this is not crucial for our overall review of adjectival passives.

subsection.heading: 5.3 Passive participle contrasts in Dutch verb raising
subsection.p: The difference between a feature checking approach to -en (ii) and its late insertion (iii), i.e., inserting the verbal passive -en under a suffixal A in PF, can be tested empirically in the syntax. Under late insertion, verbal passive participles are expected to show some transformational behaviour of V not shared by As, whereas under LF feature checking of -en, a verbal passive participle should have the same syntax as an A, because verbal and adjectival passives then come to differ only in LF.

In Dutch sequences of final verbs (where all but the underlyingly highest must be non-finite), verbal and adjectival passive participles behave differently. Verbal participles can move from their base position, italicized in (33a), over higher final verbs as in (33b), but adjectival participles must remain in their italicized base position in (34a). H. Van Riemsdijk has provided these examples:

(33)
a. . . . dat de brief verzonden
moest worden.
. . . that the letter sent must get
‘. . . that the letter must be sent.’
b. . . . dat de brief moest worden verzonden.

(34)
a. . . . dat de brief onverzonden
moest blijven.
. . . that the letter unsent must remain
‘. . . that the letter must remain unsent.’
b. *. . . dat de brief moest blijven onverzonden.

Under the verb-raising analysis advocated in Haegeman and Van Riemsdijk (1986), one may say that verbal passive participles undergo reanalysis and subsequent verb raising, while adjectival ones cannot. Furthermore, verb raising, which most likely applies at PF, is optional for a verbal passive participle (33). In contrast, Dutch verb raising to final position is obligatory for an infinitive, as italicized in (35).

(35)
a. *. . . dat Henk de brief zenden zal moeten.
*. . . dat Henk de brief zal zenden moeten.
b. . . . dat Henk de brief zal moeten zenden.
. . . that Henk the letter will must send
‘. . . that Henk will have to send the letter.’

These observations suggest that verb raising and/or movement is obligatory (in some contexts and dialects) for an item analyzed as a V, but impossible for an item analyzed as an A. That is, at the point in the derivation at which this operation applies, (a) an infinitive is unambiguously a V, (b) a verbal passive participle is analyzable as either a V or an A, and (c) an adjectival passive participle is unambiguously an A. Now according to the late insertion alternative of -en (iii), the verbal passive in a syntactic derivation (and early in PF) is precisely a V stem with an empty suffixal head A. Hence an operation such as verb raising/movement can see (‘analyze’) the verbal passive as either a V or as an A, correctly yielding both variants in (33). By contrast, an adjectival passive is unambiguously an A, with a syntactically invisible V stem inside it throughout a derivation; it must then remain in situ as in (34). Finally, an infinitive is a V and nothing else, so it must undergo verb raising/movement as in (35).

Under the feature-checking approach, the two types of passive are the same in the syntax and shouldn't differ in behavior at all. We thus see that the explanatory contrasting LF structures in (5) are more likely due to the possibility of inserting grammatical morphemes at different derivational levels than to any differences in LF feature checking of a V that moves in syntax or PF. 28

subsection.heading: 6 Evidence for Move in adjectival passives
6.1 Levin and Rappaport: relating deep direct objects to adjectival passives
subsection.p: Despite their many surface differences, we can nonetheless descriptively characterize adjectival and verbal passive phrases in very similar terms. To appreciate the empirical import of this, let's first briefly examine a class of ‘active’ adjectives derived from verbs where we cannot descriptively characterize the two classes in similar terms. Consider a large class of lexical adjectives in -ive that attach to V stems, i.e., attractive, attentive, corrosive, decisive, defensive, derisive, dismissive, evasive, exhaustive, invasive, obtrusive, offensive, perceptive, (re)active, receptive, repulsive, seductive, selective, etc. In just about every case, the types of permitted arguments with the verb and the corresponding adjective differ.

First, decide, defend, dismiss, evade, and perceive are transitive, but their adjectival counterparts are preferably intransitive, with of-phrase complements being marginal at best, e.g. *John is {decisive/defensive} of his own actions. Second, selection restrictions on corresponding arguments differ unpredictably: Magnets {attract/ *are attractive {to/of}} metals; America {often invades/*is often invasive of} the Caribbean; Those weapons were offensive ≠ Those weapons offended; Mary {repels/is repulsive to} John vs. Mary {repels/*is repulsive to} John's advances; We are selective about cheeses vs. We select (*about) cheeses, etc., etc.

The variation between adjectival passives and corresponding active verbs is nothing on this scale. In fact, the possible subjects of adjectival passives seem to be precisely those deep direct objects of verbs whose obligatory subcategorizations are otherwise respected in the passive phrases. Levin and Rappaport (1986: sections 2–3) explicitly demonstrate that any individual theta-roles, whether or not Theme is understood as in Anderson (1977), are irrelevant for determining well-formed passive adjectives. They use the following type of data to establish this generalization.

(36)
verb: They stuffed the feathers *(into the pillow).
adjective: The feathers remained stuffed *(in the pillow).
verb: They crammed the freezer (with food).
We crammed food *(into the freezer).
adjective: The freezer remained crammed (with food).
The food remained crammed *(into the freezer).
verb: We are placing our company records *(where they belong).
adjective: Our company records are placed *(where they belong) by now.
verb: The trees are being stripped {of/*with} bark.
The bark is being stripped {from/*on} those trees.
adjective: The trees look stripped {of/*with} bark.
The bark remains unstripped {from/*on} those trees.

In essence, Levin and Rappaport's results establish a syntactic passive relation between a direct object and a subject. The import of their findings is straight-forward: the theta-role of the subject of an adjectival passive is always that of the corresponding verb's deep direct object. However, they avoid reference to syntactic structure in describing these findings, as they are convinced that theta-role specifications should replace subcategorization in lexical representations. 29 They therefore paraphrase references to the fact that passive adjectives preserve verbal subcategorization, speaking for example of a “basic insight: the properties of an AP headed by an adjectival passive participle are determined by the complement structure of the base verb” (p. 637). and they summarize “the theta-role assigned to the direct argument internal to the VP headed by the verb is assigned external to the AP headed by the related adjectival passive participle . . .” (p. 643).

A little reflection shows that the syntactic generalization for adjectival passives, above in italics, is exactly what holds for verbal passives, except that ‘direct argument’ (= deep direct object) for adjectival passives is replaced for verbal passives with ‘direct object at Spell Out’. In my view, this relation is best captured, as it has been throughout the history of generative grammar, by using object to subject NP movement in adjectival passives, as suggested in Fiengo (1977). The subsequent inability to even conceive of this option is the unfortunate legacy of Wasow (1977) mentioned in introducing section 3.

Deriving adjectival passives from transformational movement immediately explains the problem faced by Anderson (1977) exemplified in (27): why adjectival passives are easier to form than middle verbs. The latter apparently require lexical specification, which comes with a cost-per-item not assessed for transformational passivization.
Let us see in more detail how Move can derive adjectival passives and account for their differences with verbal passives.

subsection.heading: 6.2 Reformulating Levin and Rappaport's ‘Sole Complement Generalization’
subsection.p: We have seen that in the perspective of Anderson (1977), the generalization (29) of section 4 should be expressed by principles of grammar, not in individual lexical items.
(29) The subject of (always intransitive) adjectival passives relates semantically to the verb root like the direct object of corresponding transitive verbs.

Small changes in (29) can lead to a central descriptive generalization about adjectival passives that encompasses the other systematic syntactic restrictions on adjectival passives: their compatibility with only deep direct objects (section 2.5) and their incompatibility with idiomatic objects (section 2.7).

First, it is the presence in the syntax of the participial stem [A -en] that somehow forces an adjectival passive's subject to relate to a deep object rather than a derived object. Second, as argued in Levin and Rappaport (1986: section 4.5), theta-roles are plausibly interpretations provided only to argument phrases, so that parts of idioms generally lack theta-roles. 30 These two considerations lead us to restate (29) as (37):

(37) Passive Adjective Condition (PAC). The subject of adjectival passives receives the theta-role that its verb root assigns to a deep direct object in an active VP. In other respects adjectival passives respect the subcategorization of the verb root. 31
The conclusion (37) is almost the same as Levin and Rappaport's (1986: 631) summary of their empirical findings for adjectival passives:
(38) Sole Complement Generalization (SCG). An argument that may stand as sole NP complement to a verb can be externalized [become the subject] by Adjectival Passive Formation (APF).

The SCG as formulated is inaccurate, however. As discussed in note 5, certain sole NP complements cannot become subjects of adjectival passives. Moreover, NP subjects of adjectival passives can only relate to direct objects; they cannot correspond to predicate nominals or measure phrases (e.g., We seemed to remain almost three weeks/*Almost three weeks seemed remained). Therefore, having a sole NP complement is not a sufficient condition for APF.

Nor is the SCG a necessary condition for APF. For example, (38) fails to predict the existence of the adjectival passives in (39a), because their subjects are not potential sole complements to verbs. These APF verbs require two complements, as the active counterparts (39b) show.

(39)
a. Roses looked strewn everywhere.
Their balconies stayed bedecked with flags for a week.
That application seems worded with exceptional care.
b. The children have strewn roses *(everywhere).
Fans were bedecking their balconies *(with flags).
Mary worded that application *(with exceptional care).

The SCG (38) is not a necessary condition for APF because adjectival passive phrases, like verbal passive phrases, must respect the subcategorization of the head verb. The descriptively adequate reformulation of the SCG is therefore the PAC (37). and if the term ‘theta-role’ is replaced by the more general term ‘interpretation’, then the PAC is nothing other than a description of deriving adjectival passives by movement of a deep direct object.

subsection.heading: 6.3 A non-problem for Move with adjectival passives
subsection.p: Even though Levin and Rappaport show that individual theta-roles are irrelevant for characterizing adjectival passives, there remains another legacy of lexicalist treatments that could prevent acceptance of using Move for this construction.

A number of researchers feel that the idiomatic lexicalized meanings of many passive adjectives, as evidenced in (40), somehow undermine any account of them in terms of transfomational movement of the object DP.

But this conclusion is a non sequitur. Chomsky's (1970) long accepted analysis of derived nominals, which also exhibit a notorious range of idiomatic and lexicalized meanings, uses – indeed is the source of using – the NP-preposing transformation for objects. The lexicalized meanings of many passive adjectives are thus no barrier to deriving adjectival passives by ‘NP movement’.

subsection.heading: 7 Lexical notation for dual level or polyfunctional morphology
subsection.p: Throughout this chapter, I have claimed that the LF difference in (5a, b) between phonologically identical adjectival and verbal passives underlies several of their surface differences. If Move can be used in deriving both passive types, the distinction in (5) should somehow correlate with how Move interacts differently with object NPs in the two constructions.

In both passives, the participial head -en can be said to agree with a moved passive subject, as this agreement is morphologically overt in many languages (section 3.3). This agreeing surface subject has its source in different pre-movement positions, however:
(41) In adjectival passives, the head [A -en] agrees with the deep direct object of the verb, by virtue of the PAC (37). This morpheme is present at LF (5a).

(42) In verbal passives, the head [A -en] agrees with a noun phrase that is a derived object of the verb, i. e., the object in the predicate phrase subsequent to transformational computation. This morpheme is absent at LF (5b).

Aside from this difference both uses of the English and other passive participle morphemes can be expressed in a single lexical entry (43). As is standard, phi-features refer to NUMBER, GENDER, and PERSON features on nominal projections:
(43) Passive participle: -en, A, +V__, phi-features of an (empty) nominal projection sister 32

The second sentences in (41) and (42) are just (5a, b) rephrased. I assume that these LF differences are simply inherited from the corresponding syntactic representations, so that ‘present/absent at LF’ is equivalent to ‘present/absent in syntax’ and ‘absent in syntax/LF’ means ‘present only in PF’. I thus rephrase (41) and (42) as follows:
(44) Adjectival Passives. An item [A -en] in the context V__ in the syntax agrees with V's deep direct object.
(45) Verbal Passives. An item [A -en] in the context V__ only in PF agrees with V's surface object.

The links between ‘deep’ and ‘present in syntax’ in (44), and ‘surface’ and ‘present only in PF’ in (45) now seem suggestive. We want to correlate these two properties of participial -en, and thus reduce all the differences between adjectival and verbal passives to one. 33 The sort of dual behavior of grammatical morphemes expressed in (44) and (45) has in recent years been the focus of increasing theoretical interest, for example in Borer (1991, 1993), Emonds (1991a, 2000), Grimshaw (1990), and Schoorlemmer (1995).

For example, Schoorlemmer's thorough study of the Russian participles examines what she terms the ‘polyfunctionality’ of several grammatical morphemes in Slavic systems. Among them one prominent example is the Russian adjectival passive ending and the homonymous ‘PPP’ (past passive participle in verbal passives), which is basically the counterpart of the polyfunctionality in (44) and (45). Most of the differences she discusses between Russian adjectival and verbal passives are similar to or even identical with the differences for English: (i) Certain Russian adjectival passives undergo degree word modification and show ‘semantic drift’, i.e., they are part of the permanent lexicon. These aspects of English adjectival passives are discussed in slightly different terms in section 2.3 above. (ii) Adjectival passives have no external argument (implicit or explicit); cf. section 2.6. (iii) A Russian counterpart to un- prefixation, namely ne- prefixation, occurs with adjectival but not verbal passives; cf. section 2.4. (iv) The verbal passive reports an event (with a possible durative adverb), while the adjectival passive reports a state; cf. section 2.1. (v) Adjectival passives can be complements of stat’ ‘become, get’ whereas verbal passives cannot be; cf. section 2.2. 34

She summarizes these results as follows: “The PPP is adjectival only with respect to its inflection, everything else is verbal, as shown by its behaviour in the diagnostics for adjectival passives” (1995: 217–222). In an earlier passage, Schoorlemmer characterizes this type of grammatical behavior as follows:

quotation.p: there seem to be two kinds of morphological processes: those that can be argued to be presyntactic [e.g., in passive adjectives] and those that can be argued to be non-presyntactic [e.g., in verbal passives] . . . the morphological output of both rules is almost entirely uniform. (Schoorlemmer 1995: 163–164)

subsection.p: The formulations (44) and (45) reflect the same dichotomy between ‘presyntactic’ and ‘non-presyntactic’.
In order to provide a theoretically satisfactory basis for expressing the polyfunctionality of the Russian PPP (i.e. -en), Schoorlemmer uses an approach developed by H. Borer:

quotation.p: for a unitary morphological module that runs parallel to syntax and also precedes and follows it, an approach to morphology named Parallel Morphology in Borer (1993) . . . Morphology . . . is a set of rules that can apply anywhere. It derives Lieber type head-adjoined structures (Lieber 1980, 1992) . . . The product of these morphological rules may be inserted at both D- and S-structure. Borer argues that the difference between two kinds of nominals (like Hebrew and English process and result nominals) is one of the levels at which the product of the morphological rules enters syntax. (1995: 171–173) 35

subsection.p: This relatively new approach to morphology, though doubtlessly still in need of refinement, seems capable of capturing the dual functionality of the passive participle morpheme [A -en] expressed above as (44) and (45). We want to derive it from the single lexical entry (43).

Adjectival passives require the Lieber type head-adjoined structure [A V − [A -en]] that results from (43) to enter a derivation presyntactically, at the beginning of a computational ‘phase’. Presyntactic insertion naturally implies that the item -en satisfies its lexical specification at that level, i.e., it must agree with a nominal projection that is its pretransformational sister. This can only be a deep direct object, so (44) follows. Moreover, since the head of the predicate phrase is a lexicalized adjective -en, no case can be assigned to any DP sister of the head. The same -en blocks any idiomatic V-Complement readings by virtue of O’Grady's (1998) Continuity Constraint; cf. note 11.

Verbal passives instantiate this same structure and lexical specification, but applied in PF. Consequently, they enter the derivation ‘nonpresyntactically’. We can improve on this rather vague term by specifying Spell Out as the appropriate input for the insertion operation. The output of the insertion is then part of PF. Satisfying its lexical requirement at Spell Out implies that -en agrees with any nominal phrase that is its sister after the (visible) transformational computation. From this follows (45). 36 Moreover, since the A head is not lexicalized at Spell Out (but only after insertion in PF), V is the visible head of the construction and both case assignment and idiom interpretation can proceed normally. The different types of agreements of -en are thus derived from its two levels of insertion (44) and (45) into the computation.

The only thing that remains to stipulate for -en is the dual level insertion itself. Apropos, Schoorlemmer (1995: section 3.3.3) rightly observes: “A related question is why there are so few morphological processes with dual properties” (p. 180). This empirical observation suggests that polyfunctionality is a marked lexical option, perhaps partly motivated diachronically; cf. note 4. What the lexical entry for -en then needs to indicate is that A can optionally, in the marked case, remain uninterpreted in LF – the property (5b) of verbal passives so frequently called on earlier to explain differences in the two passive types.

In a study attempting to develop some appropriate notations for the special lexicon of grammatical formatives, Emonds (2002) argues that while syntactic categories are never optional (every morpheme in a tree has a category), they may optionally be ignored at the LF interface. The marked option of not interpreting a category at LF can then be simply notated by parenthesizing it. If further an element so parenthesized has no other interpretable features (and -en does not, since agreement features are not interpreted), then the item optionally plays no role at LF. But items without interpretations should be inserted into the derivation only in PF, which is precisely what is needed in order to derive the results of this study. Revising (43) in this way, we derive a final and parsimonious lexical entry for the polyfunctional passive participle morpheme:
(46) Revised Passive participle: -en, (A), +V__, phi-features of an empty sister

In the reading without parentheses, A is a normal LF-interpreted syntactic category, as needed in the adjectival passive. As expected, A is interpreted as a property of the subject DP that it modifies. In the marked reading with parentheses, the category A (i.e., a ‘state’ or ‘property’) is ignored at LF; therefore -en is inserted in PF, and the verbal passive results. 37

Certain languages such as Ukrainian (Sobin 1985) and Norwegian (Åfarli 1989, 1992) have ‘transitive impersonal passives’ in which the participle has phi-features of an overt noun phrase sister. In these languages, ‘empty’ in (46) is an option rather than a necessity as in English. Various formal analyses of such distinctions are given by these authors and in Baker, Johnson, and Roberts (1989), Lappin and Shlonsky (1993), and Emonds (2000: ch. 5).

Two last details: since phi-features can originate only with nominal projections, (46) does not mention the latter. Moreover, the fact that sisterhood is the favored source for agreement is plausibly also to be derived from Universal Grammar and need not be stipulated in a lexical entry.

We thus seem to have successfully accounted for all differences between adjectival and verbal periphrastic passives with a single polyfunctional lexical entry (46) that specifies an inflection, exactly in accord with the rather bold research program for language particular properties proposed in Borer (1984a: 29).

subsection.heading: 8 Consequences of adjectival agreement in passives
subsection.p: There still remains the issue of how to best characterize what passive structures have in common: the verbal stem of a passive participle cannot assign an external theta-role to the participle's grammatical subject, even when the verb's objects remain in situ (as in Norwegian and Ukrainian). The key to these ‘dethematicized’ subjects lies, I believe, in understanding the crucial role of adjectival agreement. While this agreement is not universal, it is typical of the Indo-European family whose periphrastic passives we are trying to understand. Moreover, it has certain systematically recurring characteristics (phi-features of gender and number, interaction with case marking, absence in adverbial APs) that suggest some common cross-linguistic basis. 38

subsection.heading: 8.1 Lexical agreement of -en with objects
subsection.p: The lexical entry (46) stipulates that a certain verbal suffix, the passive participle, agrees with that verb's object. That is, the phi-features on the inserted item -en must be the same as those of any nominal projection sister at the moment of insertion, which can be pre-transformational (44) or exactly at Spell Out (45). Notice that (46) is indifferent between (i) insuring that the phi-features of A's sister are those independently assigned to A, due to the general agreement of adjectives with their subjects, and (ii) assigning the phi-features of A's sister to a featureless empty A (which then appear on -en in PF).

Some puzzling related but non-passive paradigms in several Romance and Slavic systems strongly suggest that the reference to object agreement in (46) is on the right track. As mentioned in section 1.1, many of these languages additionally use their passive participle morpheme to form an active periphrastic past tense (e.g., the French passé composé and Italian passato prossimo), in which the participle does not agree with the subject. With some language-particular restrictions, the participial morpheme -en in this active tense nonetheless agrees in phi-features with a deep object, i.e., a DP sister, just as stated in (46).

Exact determination of the variable conditions on this non-passive object agreement is orthogonal to our concerns here. At one extreme, Modern Spanish active perfective participles, also based on the passive form, never agree with an object. In other systems only empty objects trigger agreement, e.g., in Standard French they must be bound by a clitic or a fronted constituent such as a clefted or questioned direct object. Agreement of -en in adult Standard Italian generally requires empty DPs in deep object position, under conditions that are similar though not identical to Standard French. We see the relevant contrast in French in (47), where bold indicates feminine plural suffixes; ti is a trace of the moved direct object.
