‘It's those beautiful doors that that woman has quickly repaint-ed.’

In yet other systems, -en agrees even with overt objects. Perhaps the most striking contrast is within Italian. Antinucci and Miller (1976) and Volterra (1976) report that at a certain stage of child Italian, the agreement of participial -en with all direct objects in the passato prossimo is uniform. 39 Borer and Wexler (1992: 153) describe this as follows: “Presumably, the learner initially tries a ‘simple’ rule, like ‘agree with the D-structure object’.” 40

The active participle ending -en thus seems exceptional only in being an adjective that does not agree with subjects, as seen in (47a). 41 Otherwise though, its lexical entry must be an extension of (46), since it shares every other characteristic of the passive participle: its category (A), its host (V), and its phonological form. In addition, the object agreement of -en in active tenses that has led several authors to conclude that its central property in all its uses is potential agreement with a verb's object, precisely as specified in (46), albeit at different levels and under different conditions. Among the passive constructions, this apparent object agreement is obviated just in those cases where the language allows expletive subjects (without phi-features), which in, e.g., Norwegian and Ukrainian include even VPs that contain overt object noun phrases.

We find in the literature at least four mechanisms for effecting the phi-feature agreement mandated in (46) between deep object noun phrases and participial -en. In each case the mechanism extends beyond passive constructions; all extend agreement with null objects to other uses of -en. While I am a partisan of this general approach, the exact conditions determining these limitations on agreement clearly lead outside the domain where adjectival passives have a special role, so my summary of these four mechanisms is cursory.

A first proposal in McA’Nulty (1990) limits itself to generalizing in French over object traces in passives and A-bar bound traces, as suggested by the paradigms just mentioned. Second, Lefebvre (1988) develops a more general system in terms of ‘Move Case’, thus making precise government and binding's often vague concept of ‘case absorption’ by -en. She summarizes, “agreement morphology on the past participle spells out the features of the trace of the NP governed by the past participle.”

A third proposal is the widely adopted hypothesis that all phi-feature agreements are defined on Specifier–Head configurations. Since the non-passive uses of -en agreement involve deep objects (e.g., the French and Italian paradigms cited above), Kayne (1989a) proposes that it takes place after the agreeing object nominals move to relatively low Specifier positions within extended verbal projections. Borer and Wexler also follow this approach (1992). 42

Finally, Emonds (2000: ch. 4) argues that morphological inflections instantiate a widespread phenomenon called ‘Alternative Realization’. Under this view, grammatical features are interpretable only in certain base positions (e.g., phi-features are interpreted only on D). However, they can also occur in non-base positions on lexically stipulated closed class elements (usually on an adjacent head) if they thereby contribute to Economy of Derivation. Accordingly, the entry for -en stipulates (only) that it ‘alternatively realizes’ phi-features of objects, with differences among the passive systems of English, German, and Norwegian attributed to slightly different lexical specifications. A general restriction to local contexts in the definition of (unmarked) Alternative Realization renders unnecessary any mention of ‘empty sister’ in (46).

We need not decide among these four alternatives. However this agreement of -en with an object is finally formalized, the analytic passive sub-case of (46), robustly overt in several grammatical systems, fully unifies adjectival and verbal passives. All their differences are due to the levels of insertion of -en, as explicated in section 7. and somewhat surprisingly, we will see in the next section that (46) also leads directly to explaining Åfarli's ‘essential property of (all) passives’, the suppression of external theta-roles in SPEC(IP).

Needless to say, object agreement in participles still leaves unanswered questions: (i) Why and under what conditions do expletive subjects cancel the need for it? (ii) Why do only certain grammars exhibit it in active composed pasts with overt object noun phrases? (iii) How is this -en agreement (46) related to expressing what is familiarly called ‘object to subject movement’, i.e., is ‘subject–object agreement’ possibly a prerequisite for the latter? (Cf. Emonds 2000: ch. 5.) But since these intriguing questions lead well outside the realm of specifically adjectival passives, this study leaves them for future research.

subsection.heading: 8.2 External theta-role suppression (dethematicization)
subsection.p: If adjectival passives are derived by movement, they show that the common property of passives has nothing to do with some subject position ‘losing’ an ability to express a theta-role, since the works cited in section 2.6 show that no such underlying position or theta-role is ever part of a derivation of adjectival passives. Rather, what makes the subject of any (verbal or adjectival) passive clause ‘theta-free’ (and hence, when expletives are unavailable, forces movement of some DP to this position) is the fact that agreement with a subject simply makes the latter inaccessible for being interpreted within any phrase headed by a passive participle. That is, nothing outside a phrase whose head V has adjectival morphology can serve as an argument of that V. If we can explain why – why the feature specification of the A head of the passive participle should block theta-role assignment to SPEC(IP) – we thereby account for Åfarli's ‘essential property of the passive’.

We want to do this with no stipulation about passive structures, using only generally justifiable statements of grammatical theory. The key distinction, overtly morphological in several Romance languages, lies in the adjectival agreements of -en. The following French examples from section 3.3 show a typical situation: all passive participles overtly agree with the surface subject as shown in bold brackets in (48a, b) while active participles do not (48c).

(48)
a. A mon arrivée, ces jolies
portes semblaient [AP

‘At my arrival, those pretty doors seemed already repainted.’

‘Those pretty doors were quickly repainted by the renter during my visit.’

‘Those women have all the same painted only by necessity.’

Using the representations for adjectival agreement just developed, we can account for this contrast with what is actually a generalization of the Head Movement Constraint (Travis 1984). The HAC (49) is motivated by the same paradigms as the HMC but is also more general than the HMC.
(49) Head Accessibility Constraint (HAC). In a structure . . . Xj . . . [YP . . . Z0 . . . ], Xj can be related only with the least embedded Z0 specified for inherent features within YP. 43

There are two cases, j = 0 and j = 1. The case that j = 0 is Travis's HMC, with the slight and welcome modification that a completely featureless intervening head doesn't trigger the HMC; a computational step can relate two heads X0 and Z0 over an intermediate head Y0 only if Y0 completely lacks features. In particular, a lexical stem V of a participial AP can relate to a higher head in LF, e.g., a tense or modal in I, only if both the head [A Ø] of AP and any auxiliary V have no features. This occurs in derivations where the lexical entry (46) assigns phi-features to A only in PF, i.e., in active perfects and certain reflexive clauses. 44 In contrast, participles in all analytic passive clauses agree in phi-features with their subject DPs in the syntax, so that the role of (46) is to verify that phi-features already on [A Ø] are compatible with those of an object.

What accounts for dethematicization in passives is the case where j = 1 in the HAC, e.g., where Xj is a subject DP position. 45 As desired, (49) says that a subject in SPEC(IP) is inaccessible to V0 (= Z0) in the syntax whenever the head of the participle (= Y0) is specified for features, as in fact the A0 head is in the syntax of both types of periphrastic passives. Consequently, ces jolies portes in SPEC(IP) in (48a, b) simply cannot relate to the verb stem repein-, as external argument or in any other way. This prediction of the HAC then finally expresses the ‘essential property of the passive’ that we have been hoping to derive throughout this study.

On the other hand, the DP ces jolies portes in (48a, b) does indeed receive an LF iterpretation: it has the property expressed by the adjectival head -en that modifies it. The agreeing phi-features of -en transmit to the subject the property of playing the role of the phrase Y it agrees with, namely the object noun phrase in the proposition expressed entirely within the AP: ‘X repaints Y, where Y = the direct object’.

In contrast to passives, the right hand morphological head [A -t] of the French active participle in (47a, b) and (48c) is an exceptional non-agreeing adjective, like those in the idioms avoir chaud ‘feel hot’, tenir bon ‘hold on’, peser lourd ‘weigh a lot’, etc., it is lexically specified to not agree with a subject DP. This participle can thus acquire phi-features only in PF, due to the object agreement induced by (46). Hence the HAC (53) allows the stem V (re)pein- to relate to the DPs in a higher SPEC(IP) outside the AP in these examples, because the PF features on -t are not part of the syntax or LF. The only factor which could inhibit such a relation would be an intervening head V specified for features. But the intervening auxiliary head avoir ‘have’ with an active participle is precisely a V that is also empty except in PF. Therefore, the DPs cette femme/ces femmes in (47a, b) and (48c) relate to the Vs (re)pein- as their subject, even though these Vs are contained in both a higher VP headed by a/ont ‘have’ and an AP headed by -t ‘-en’. 46

In this section, we have been able to account for Åfarli's ‘essential property of the passive’ (31) by generalizing Travis's Head Movement Constraint to the ‘Head Accessibility Constraint’ (49). The crucial ‘dethematicization’ of the external argument position in passive phrases is crucially due to the fact that both types of passives are inflected adjectives, i.e., they have feature specifications in syntax that make impossible any relation between their subject and the V stem to which they are attached. The HAC thus prevents any of a verb's theta-roles from being realized outside the passive AP. Nothing in this explanation of dethematicization requires reference to any special passive properties, once we understand both the syntactic nature of adjectival agreement and the far-reaching syntactic effects of the passive morpheme's unified lexical entry (46). 47

subsection.heading: 8.3 An additional consequence of the Head Accessibility Constraint
subsection.p: We can examine a different adjectival construction to see how the HAC fares when confronted with possibly disconfirming data. Let us again consider the class of lexical adjectives formed by attaching -ive to V stems, i.e., attractive, corrosive, decisive, defensive, etc. French cognate counterparts of many of these, like other French adjectives, agree with their subjects: masculine défensif(s) and feminine défensive(s). For many adjectives in this class, it seems like the subject of the adjective is also the subject of the verb stem: one who is decisive also decides, something that is offensive also offends, etc.

According to the HAC (49), however, the subjects of these APs cannot directly relate to these V as subjects, because the agreeing suffixes [A -if/-ive] block accessibility between V and these subject phrases. and the fact that the restrictions on the subjects of corresponding Vs and As are so different suggests that this is correct. As reviewed in section 6.1, one who receives visitors or gifts is not receptive, one who repels attacks is not repulsive, the goal phrases for attractive must be animate, etc.

There is a regularity, however: the adjective seems appropriate for a subset of cases where the verb stem can be used as a bare predicate. Thus in most cases, if ‘X is V-ive’, then typically ‘X V-s . . .’ in a subset of contexts in which ‘X-V-s . . .’ is appropriate. Plausibly, the lexical entry of a V in this formation associates the suffixation frame ___ +ive with both these limitations and also a subject variable X, possibly sometimes giving the latter a ±ANIMATE value. (Only people seem perceptive and selective, although animals can perceive and climactic conditions can select.) In this way, the adjectival ending serves to transmit to its own subject the external theta-role of the V stem. The subject of the adjective then has the property of one who fulfills that role X in the associated proposition (e.g., ‘X repels people’ but not ‘X repels attacks’). 48 But in all this, the V itself does not need to directly relate to the subject DP in, e.g., SPEC(IP). So it seems that the HAC is not undermined by typical adjectival modification, which does not involve passive ‘dethematicization’.

subsection.heading: 9 Conclusion: the unity of syntax and morphology
subsection.p: We have reviewed the history of treatments of the adjectival passives, concluding that Fiengo's (1977) basic idea was correct: this construction should be derived by NP movement, just like verbal passives. The many differences between adjectival and verbal periphrastic passives, which reproduce themselves cross-linguistically, are due not to their genesis in different grammatical components but rather to their morphological structure entering a syntactic derivation at different levels. Adjectival passive -en is inserted essentially at the outset of transformational computation (causing it to be mistaken for a base construction). Verbal passive -en is inserted only at Spell Out, with the result that it has been mistaken for a VP when it is in fact an AP of a special sort, one whose head A is not interpreted in LF.

We have found that almost every well-known property of either type of periphrastic passive is intimately connected to its participial morphology. Its category A and the insertion level of its morphemic realization -en determine (i) the suppression of the external theta-role, (ii) the missing external argument and unavailability of case in (only) adjectival passives, (iii) the type of verb which selects each passive type, (iv) the types of modifiers which each type tolerates, and (v) their general syntactic distribution. To the extent these conclusions are warranted, we must conclude that studying the passive independent of its morphology is as fruitless as studying its morphology in isolation. The unity of morphology and syntax is not only an a priori desideratum based on parsimony but apparently a methodological necessity.

A somewhat more exotic conclusion of this study has been that the verbal passive, considered in early generative grammar to be the ‘true passive’ and straightforwardly taken as the basis of the adjectival passive in several studies (e.g., Bresnan 1982d; Levin and Rappaport 1986), is rather the lexically marked and diachronically later variant of the construction, as proposed in Schoorlemmer (1995: 180–183). This conclusion is expressed formally by the use of parentheses in (46). That is, parenthesizing a grammatical element's syntactic category opens the way for its use as a semantically empty ‘inflection’ (if a bound morpheme) or ‘function word’ (if a free morpheme).

This conclusion brings us back around to the chapter's subtitle, from Dumas's Man in the Iron Mask. The verbal passive, king of transformations in the domain of syntax, has for decades shaped the beliefs and practices of the loyal subjects, to say nothing of the cabinet's. Examples: movements give rise to co-indexed chains rather than vice versa; syntax can be fruitfully pursued with at most lip service to ‘autonomous’ morphology. But the king has a double, and this double carries the same traits as the king: it is adjectival, it is a verbal suffix, and it agrees with object nominals. Moreover, it is adjectival in meaning, not just in exterior form. So the double doesn't look like the king but rather the king looks like the double, and derives its kingship precisely from being a look-alike. Strangely, the double has been locked in an impregnable fortress, the lexicon, where few transformationalists have cared to venture; and the kingdom's beliefs and practices have developed during this imprisonment. When we now bring the double out of this fortress, the king will have two faces and the loyal subjects may lose their bearings. The beliefs and practices established during the kingship, perhaps even those of the cabinet, may have to change.

4 Ackema (1995) proposes that dual or second usages of suffixes such as English passive -en may arise “because they serve to fill in the gaps in the morphological system in diachronic change” (cited in Schoorlemmer 1995: 181). For example, when the suffixes of the Latin synthetic passives were lost (Romance languages typically show no reflexes of them), Latin analytic perfect passives formed from the copula plus an adjectival passive participle were extended to a second use in Romance, that of a verbal passive, thereby filling the morphological gaps. Thus, Romance adjectival passives seem historically the prior type.
5 Levin and Rappaport's (1986) study of adjectival passives might attribute some of the examples in (4), e.g., with verbs like hand and slip, to their ‘Sole Complement Generalization’ (SCG):

subsection.p: (i) Sole Complement Generalization. An argument that may stand as sole NP complement to a verb can be externalized by Adjectival Passive Formation.
However, the SCG can't be the only restriction on forming adjectival passives, since in view of the examples in (ii), those in (4) all counter-exemplify (i).
(ii) They {approached/left} New York. Drinks {accompanied/followed} dinner. During the summer, we try to {avoid/escape} cities. They practiced {dribbling/throwing} the ball.
So some other characteristic of verb classes must be incompatible with adjectival passives.

p.span: 6 The fact that adjectival passives describe a property is mentioned in Bresnan's (1982d) lexical rule of conversion, which adds this interpretation as well as the category A to verbal participles. It seems obvious that ‘property’ or ‘state’ is simply the unmarked interpretation of A.

7 The formulation (5) is neutral as to how syntax derives this LF alternation. It could be that -en is present in both types of syntactic derivation, with its uninterpretable A feature checked off prior to LF in verbal passives (in the terminology of Chomsky 1995c), or that the -en of verbal passives is inserted under A only in PF (as in Emonds 2000: ch. 5). Sections 3.3, 5.2, and 7 return to these alternatives.

8 In general, adjectival passives can themselves be divided into lexicalized adjectives, which like most other adjectives are compatible with a full range of degree words, and those that seem ‘created anew’ at each use. The latter often sound unacceptable with adjectival modifiers and in this sense resemble verbal passives.
9 Similarly, Emonds (1991a) claims that a range of quantifiers and determiners which modify only nouns cannot modify English gerunds headed by V + [N ing] because this N is empty in LF.

10 Authors who agree that verbal passives contain covert agent phrases (which is all that is necessary for the analysis here) disagree as to its nature. Chomsky (1986b) and Roberts (1987) argue that it cannot be the same as the PRO subject of infinitives. Emonds (2000: ch. 10) claims that Chomsky's examples are inconclusive because they are based on properties of ‘obligatory PRO’, while a covert agent phrase has discourse-bound properties of so-called ‘optional’ PRO.
11 This restriction on idiom formation is a slight strengthening of O’Grady's (1998: 284) well researched ‘Continuity Constraint’ on idioms (i), where he defines ‘chain’ as in (ii):

li.p: The Continuity Constraint. An idiom's component parts must form a chain.
The string x . . . y . . . z . . . (order irrelevant) forms a chain iff x licenses y and z, or if x licenses y and y licenses z.

p.span: 12 In other words, the italicized phrasal complements XP of adjectival passives in (i), like those of morphologically derived nominals in (ii), must be non-idiomatic:

li.p: The dinner seemed made from leftovers.
They sounded fully informed of your intentions.
The maintenance of these roads is costly.
His payment of huge sums didn't result in any entertainment of poor children.

p.span: 13 Calling a step in the history of generative analyses a ‘mistake’ refers only to how it has been ultimately evaluated by most Chomskyan practitioners. Adherents of other frameworks may consider such a step as a crucial breakthrough.

14 The structure-preserving constraint (SPC) of Emonds (1976) is more than an observation that operations such as the passive movements reproduce base structures; it also specifies the exact conditions for when landing sites do not require base structures. In mimimalist terms, part of structure preservation (in the original stronger sense of category preservation) means that the possible non-vacuous outputs of Merge and Move are structurally identical at given points in a derivation. In one sense, feature checking may predict this: if in any given position Move and Merge necessarily check the same features, this part of the SPC may follow.

subsection.p: But the SPC further specifies conditions under which structure preservation does not occur, i.e., the conditions under which Move and Merge do not have the same effects. In other words, certain Moves at the root of a tree prevent further Merges. The promissory note on structure preservation in Chomsky (1995c: section 7.2) seems to shed no light on how feature checking addresses this issue.

p.span: 15 The exceptional English A-NP combination in very near the station may be a hybrid of an AP very near to the station and a PP right near the station.

16 In particular, ‘passive auxiliaries’ are those V with the frame ___AP that are least semantically specific: be and get. Most of the Germanic and Romance languages with similar analytic passives use translations of one or both of these.

17 While it is obvious that be does not contribute to LF, it might seem that get does. Emonds (2000: ch. 5) argues that while the distribution of get seems restricted by a following verb's ‘change of state’ feature (?get owned, ?get hated, ?get known), no difference in interpretation is observed in pairs such as {get/be} examined by, {get/be} built by, {get/be} scared by, etc.
18 Archaic and sometimes semantically irregular options such as burnt, proven, and supposéd are sort of ‘exceptions that prove the rule’.
19 In contrast, the composed past of a verb in French does not agree with a subject when the auxiliary is avoir ‘have’:

row.entry: ‘That woman has all the same painted only by necessity.’

subsection.p: These kinds of patterns are commonplace in traditional grammars of languages such as French, German, and Spanish, and so will not be exemplified in detail here.

p.span: 20 An alternative to such insertion would be for a separate morphological operation to ‘add on’ an A-headed structure in PF to a simple syntactic V. But this ad hoc solution for the morphology explains neither the selection of verbal participles by be and get, nor their more general syntactic distribution reviewed in the next subsection. In addition, derivationally changing a V to [A V − [A en]] would contravene Chomsky's (1995c) programmatic Inclusiveness Condition (transformational operations can't introduce new material) more violently than late insertion into an independently justified syntactic slot. Consequently, the optimal syntactic target for the verbal passive participle seems to be [A V − [A Ø]].

21 Freidin claims (1975: 395) that passive rather than active verbs are listed in the lexicon and (p. 396) that his formalism “must be stated in terms of semantic functions rather than syntactic categories.” A consequence is that verbs with two passives (give, take advantage of, allow, etc.) each require two lexical passive verbs in the lexicon.
22 Van Riemsdijk (1983a) provides an important bridge linking a generative perspective on abstract case to the traditional understanding that accusative case is unavailable in the absence of V.

subsection.p: He further questions the standard version of the Case Filter, based on the availability of apparent ‘default morphological cases’ in many constructions in many languages, e.g., German. Rephrasing his concern, why are some noun phrases lacking categories which assign them case ill-formed, while default case allows other such noun phrases to be well-formed? This study retains a Case Filter of the original sort, assuming that any default cases are limited to noun phrases in Specifiers not linked by movement to argument (A-) positions. This formulation partly answers Van Riemsdijk's objections, but detailed justification is not straightforward and would lead us too far afield.

p.span: 23 Baker, Johnson, and Roberts (1989: section 4) discuss and try to circumvent, almost desperately it seems to me, the mounting evidence against attributing case a central role in accounting for the passive; cf. especially their note 10. In the twilight of government and binding, they “are forced to conclude, following Sobin (1985), that the absorption of accusative Case is a cross-linguistically more variable property of passive than the absorption of a &thgr;-role” (p. 236).

24 Minimalism itself, to the extent it is based on empirical paradigms, can be traced to abandoning a case-based ‘forced government’ account (30) and embracing an ‘attract’ account of passives (31), under the at least tacit influence of the cited studies. Passive movement in minimalism is universally motivated by the ‘EPP property’ of the landing site, satisfied by Movement in a situation where it cannot be satisfied by Merge. But a deeper examination of these issues would lead squarely into the territory of the verbal passive, and away from the particular focus of this study.

25 These paradigms and arguments are from Emonds (2000: chapter 5). Government binding treatments mention this type of example from time to time, often suggesting that some kind of ad hoc inherent case can be assigned to the italicized noun phrases. This line of thought sheds no light on the problem, however. Since noun phrase complements of lexical adjectives typically can have ‘inherent case’ cross-linguistically, one remains at a loss to explain why the adjectival counterparts (32) of (18) are nonetheless uniformly out (i.e., why inherent case is unavailable just where we most expect it).

26 One can still maintain that noun phrases moved in passives don't receive case, if one holds that structural cases are always assigned optionally. Emonds (1985: ch. 1) develops this perspective on case assignment; if a DP doesn't receive case from V (whether or not the V may assign case), this DP may move to get case, e.g., into the surface position of SPEC(IP).

27 A variant on (i) relates adjectival and verbal passive participles via unaffixed ‘conversion’, as in Bresnan (1982d) and Levin and Rappaport (1986: section 4.3). That is, the two constructions would share a common stem but be syntactically distinct like a noun-verb pair smoke/smoke; one would derive from the other by zero affixation. There are reasons to reject this approach, however. First, conversion only rarely affects morphologically derived forms: while the noun commission doubles as a verb, the more typical transmission, contraction, communion and contrition do not. Second, conversion typically relates two phonologically identical and semantically close forms that do not share syntax. But as seen in section 3, adjectival and verbal passives share a lot of syntax. Third, Schoorlemmer (section III.2.3.2) provides extensive arguments against using conversion to express the morphological relatedness of Russian adjectival passives and passive perfective (verbal) participles, drawing on special properties of its tense and aspect systems. The participial syntax of Germanic and Slavic languages is similar enough to expect that conversion cannot be completely wrong for the Slavic systems and yet right for Germanic.
28 In any case, feature checking in LF of a V that itself doesn't move in LF seems essentially incoherent.

subsection.p: One can of course both reject late insertion and insist that the feature-checking in both kinds of passives is the same, but then one has no account of any differences between them, i.e., such a theory ends up with nothing to say about any of the contrasting passive paradigms. Recent studies often insist on theoretical simplicity of this and that sort, at the cost of accounting for few if any paradigms.

p.span: 29 Thus, Levin and Rappaport begin their section 4.1: “In accordance with the program initiated in Chomsky (1981), we eschew the explicit use of subcategorization frames in lexical entries as a representation of the complement structure of verbs.” Consequently, after establishing their empirical conclusion, the second half of their essay reformulates their result in terms of theta-grids (taking issue with various competing semantic formulations). In my view, their choice of a semantics-based lexical framework makes it impossible to express their main result in a natural way, namely, that adjectival passive phrases lack exactly that overt DP that is licensed by the lexical frame +___DP.

30 Levin and Rappaport's vague term ‘argument’ should perhaps be replaced by a more testable concept such as ‘potentially referring phrase’. NPs in some idioms may exceptionally potentially refer, consequently receiving a theta-role and appearing in adjectival passives. Thus ?Sam will spill the beans before anyone else spills them sounds at least marginally acceptable, so the beans may be a theme. This would license the idiom in adjectival passives: ?The beans now seem spilled.
31 ‘Object’ in (37) can also refer to objects of stranded P. I have not made an analysis here of stranded prepositions in passives found in English in both verbal (i) and adjectival (ii) variants:

row.entry: This problem is being attended to.
That couch got sat on soon afterwards.
It is a long unattended to problem.
That couch looks more sat on than I thought.

subsection.p: The stranded P in the first example in (ii) is puzzling because English pre-nominal adjective phrases typically terminate in a head A, i.e., such an A must be adjacent to the N-projection it modifies. Perhaps the required adjacency forbids only intervening phrases. (Along similar lines, postverbal particles do not interfere with the adjacency usually required between English verbs and their object.)

In any case, the approach here removes a problem posed by ‘P-stranding’ for a case account of passive movement, since stranded Ps generally assign case. Since movement here is not caused by lack of case, the fact of movement with stranded Ps becomes unremarkable.

p.span: 32 Pseudo-passives fall under this formulation if they are derived by ‘detaching’ a governing P from its object (or otherwise rendering it invisible) in the context V___.

33 Recall that a lexicalized A blocks all case-assignment in adjectival passives (44), while the V in verbal passives (45) can assign case to objects, including double objects. Moreover, non-referential object phrases in idioms are compatible with (45) but not (44). These independent factors reviewed earlier should be consequences of imposing the agreements in (44) and (45) at different levels.

34 I omit three further distinctions analyzed by Schoorlemmer, which represent specifically Russian reflexes of polyfunctionality and are interesting in their own right. They would require preliminary discussion of Russian morphology (the genitive of negation), stylistics (the long form of adjectives), and aspect (her ‘perfectivity restriction’, to which she devotes most of her chapter 4), and thus take us too far afield.
35 Borer (1991) is an earlier, more accessible reference on Parallel Morphology. In her (43), Schoorlemmer exemplifies a Lieber type head adjoined structure with a Polish result nominal:

subsection.p: A similar theory of morphological analysis, but one that denies the need to distinguish a separate morphological component, is presented in Emonds (2000: chs. 3–5). Under this view, ‘morphology’ is simply the name of what results phonologically when lexical items composed entirely of grammatical features are additionally specified as ‘bound’, i.e., requiring a sister within an X0 domain.

p.span: 36 My version of dual level lexical insertion (cf. Emonds 2000: ch. 4) tries to respect the spirit of Chomsky's (1995c) Inclusiveness Condition: new structure should not be added during a derivation. Therefore, even though the morpheme -en is itself absent from verbal passive participles during the first part of a derivation, its category A should be present and empty; cf. sections 2 and especially 3.3 above.

37 Borer and Wexler (1987) propose a government and binding analysis of passives whereby verbal passives contain traces (A-chains) and adjectival passives do not. They attribute the later acquisition of verbal passives to a difficulty with acquiring A-chains. In the analysis of passives based directly on the lexical formulation (46), the later acquisition of verbal passives is due to the marked nature of ‘cancelling’ syntactic categories at the LF interface by means of the parenthesis notation.

38 Emonds (2000: ch. 5) argues that much of the grammar of APs derives from their being subject to the Case Filter, as in Stowell (1981). Non-agreeing adjectives, including perfective -en, are in general those endowed with an inherent case feature that obviates subject agreement. Other realizations of case are adverbial -ly and agreement itself. This particular mode of explanation is not at issue here.

39 Borer and Wexler (1992) cite the following summary of Antinucci and Miller (1976): “Up to a certain age, variable from child to child and ranging roughly from 2;0 to 2;5, the rule of agreement between transitive past participles and their grammatical object is never violated.”

40 Borer and Wexler's simple rule is precisely (46), which I claim is at the centre of passive phenomena as well. They reject verbal agreement with objects, however, since they wish to subsume this agreement under SPEC–HEAD agreement, along the lines of Kayne (1989a); see below in the text.

subsection.p: As they observe, a partisan of (46) has to explain why the adult rule is restricted to only empty objects. In the framework in Emonds (2000: ch. 4), agreement patterns ‘alternatively realize’ features away from their canonical LF positions; sometimes these features are also spelled out in the canonical positions and sometimes they are not. Unmarked Alternative Realization in fully developed adult grammars is used mainly to achieve economy; that is, for avoiding ‘doubling.’ Thus the child Italian rule, whereby -en doubles overt objects, would be a marked option for adults and so is superseded by a more restricted variant.

p.span: 41 Several instances of exceptional non-agreeing adjectives in French are discussed in Emonds (2000: ch. 5): avoir chaud ‘be hot’, peser lourd ‘weigh heavy’, tenir bon ‘hold on’, etc.

42 The material in this study seems orthogonal to the question of whether traditional VPs should all be analyzed as functional category projections (so-called ‘small vPs’ of some sort) with object noun phrases located in some Specifier, as Kayne's proposal requires.
43 Contextual features on Z0, for example whatever differentiates be and have, are irrelevant.

44 French and Italian have active participles whose auxiliary, like the passive auxiliary être/essere, ‘be’ agrees with their surface subject in, for example, reflexive sentences. Such agreements might seem to counterexemplify the HAC, since in these sentences the verb's agent theta-role is assigned to this subject, as in French Cette femme s’est peinte ‘That woman has painted herself.’

subsection.p: But in this construction, -en acquires agreement features only after être is inserted in PF as a result of the reflexive clitic. (Spanish reflexives which don't trigger a change in auxiliary exhibit no agreement.) Since these reflexive-induced agreement features on -en don't appear in the derivation of LF, they are irrelevant (invisible) for a principle blocking a theta-role relation between a subject and a V (respectively Xj and Z0 in the HAC).

p.span: 45 If VP and NP have more than one functional projection in their maximal ‘extended projections’ (IP and DP respectively), then (53) should perhaps include all but the topmost extended projections of YP, since I and SPEC(IP) need access to V, and D and SPEC(DP) to N.

subsection.p: We might also decide to include all extended projections of VP and NP under the term YP in (53). This would permit directly relating C to V (as in analyses countenancing ‘long head movement’ of V to C) and also V to the N heads of direct objects, as in Baker's (1988a) noun incorporation. Moreover, it would allow selection restrictions to pair V with object Ns, skipping D. All these seem like acceptable, even welcome consequences.

p.span: 46 I will not try here to recast everything in terms of some kind of ‘XP-internal subject hypothesis’, where XP includes any type of phrase. The VP-internal subject hypothesis of Zagona (1982) has indeed played an important role in improved analyses of causative and restructuring complements. However, the analyses of these constructions in Emonds (2000: ch. 6) indicates the inadequacy of a commitment to uniform phrase internal subjects.

47 The reason this explanation has been a long time coming is the agreed ‘division of labor’ between ‘syntactic theorists’ and ‘morphological specialists’, as advocated for example in Aronoff (1994: 134): “But within a lexeme-based framework in which morphology and syntax are autonomous, what Passive consists of syntactically is not directly relevant to its morphological realization . . . For my purposes, the question is just not interesting. Conversely, its morphology has no bearing on its syntax and should not be used as evidence for one syntactic analysis or another.”

subsection.p: This study has shown that satisfactory descriptions of all the main grammatical components of Indo-European periphrastic passives require a tight integration of morphology and syntax. Along similar lines, Kubo (1992) shows that the much wider range of passivizable NP positions in Japanese is directly linked to the V category of its passive morphology, which contrasts with the adjectival nature of the Indo-European periphrastic passives.

p.span: 48 On similar lines, the lexical entry for the adjectival suffix -able, which is often said to also form passive adjectives, transmits to its subject not an external theta-role but that of a direct object.
